searchDocs.title: API Reference
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: REST API Endpoints​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO exposes several REST API endpoints for retrieving analytics data:

searchDocs.title: Analytics Data​
searchDocs.content: GET /wp-json/qa-zero/v1/analytics   Parameters:  start_date: Start date for data range (YYYY-MM-DD)end_date: End date for data range (YYYY-MM-DD)metrics: Comma-separated list of metrics to retrieve

searchDocs.title: Heatmap Data​
searchDocs.content: GET /wp-json/qa-zero/v1/heatmap   Parameters:  page_id: ID of the page to retrieve heatmap data fortype: Type of heatmap (click, scroll, movement)start_date: Start date for data range (YYYY-MM-DD)end_date: End date for data range (YYYY-MM-DD)

searchDocs.title: Session Recordings​
searchDocs.content: GET /wp-json/qa-zero/v1/sessions   Parameters:  page_id: (Optional) Filter by page IDstart_date: Start date for data range (YYYY-MM-DD)end_date: End date for data range (YYYY-MM-DD)limit: Maximum number of sessions to return

searchDocs.title: WordPress Hooks​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO provides several WordPress hooks for extending functionality:

searchDocs.title: Actions​
searchDocs.content: qa_zero_before_track: Fired before tracking data is collectedqa_zero_after_track: Fired after tracking data is collectedqa_zero_process_data: Fired when data is being processedqa_zero_generate_report: Fired when a report is generated

searchDocs.title: Filters​
searchDocs.content: qa_zero_tracking_data: Filter tracking data before it's storedqa_zero_analytics_data: Filter analytics data before it's displayedqa_zero_heatmap_data: Filter heatmap data before it's displayedqa_zero_session_data: Filter session data before it's displayed

searchDocs.title: JavaScript API​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO provides a JavaScript API for interacting with the tracking system:  // Track a custom event QAZero.trackEvent('event_name', { category: 'category', label: 'label', value: 123 }); // Exclude an element from tracking QAZero.excludeElement(document.getElementById('element-id')); // Pause tracking temporarily QAZero.pauseTracking(); // Resume tracking QAZero.resumeTracking();

searchDocs.title: QA ZERO Architecture
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: System Overview​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO consists of several key components:  Core Tracking System: JavaScript code that collects user interaction dataData Storage: File-based and database storage for collected dataData Processing: Background processes that analyze and aggregate dataAdmin Interface: WordPress admin panels for viewing analytics and configuring the system

searchDocs.title: Core Tracking System​
searchDocs.content: The tracking system is implemented as JavaScript that is injected into WordPress pages. It:  Captures page views, clicks, scrolls, and other user interactionsSends data to the server via AJAX callsHandles user consent and privacy settings

searchDocs.title: Data Storage​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO uses a hybrid storage approach:  Raw data is stored in files in the wp-content/qa-zero-data directoryProcessed data is stored in WordPress database tablesSession recordings are stored as compressed JSON files

searchDocs.title: Data Processing​
searchDocs.content: Data processing is primarily handled by WordPress cron jobs that:  Aggregate raw data into meaningful metricsGenerate heatmaps from click and scroll dataCalculate conversion rates and other KPIs

searchDocs.title: Admin Interface​
searchDocs.content: The admin interface is integrated into the WordPress admin panel and provides:  Dashboard widgets for quick insightsDetailed reports and visualizationsConfiguration options for tracking and privacy settings

searchDocs.title: Data Flow​
searchDocs.content: User visits a page with QA ZERO tracking codeJavaScript collects interaction dataData is sent to the server via AJAXRaw data is stored in filesCron jobs process the raw dataProcessed data is stored in the databaseAdmin interface displays the processed data

searchDocs.title: DNS Setup Instructions for docs.qazero.com
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Prerequisites​
searchDocs.content: Access to your domain's DNS settings (typically through your domain registrar)GitHub Pages site already deployed

searchDocs.title: 1. Configure GitHub Pages​
searchDocs.content: The repository is already configured to use the custom domain through:  A CNAME file in the repository with docs.qazero.comGitHub Pages settings in the repository settings

searchDocs.title: 2. DNS Configuration​
searchDocs.content: To point your domain to GitHub Pages, you need to add the following DNS records:  Option 1: Apex Domain Configuration (Recommended)​  If you're using the apex domain (docs.qazero.com), add these A records:  Type	Host	Value	TTLA	@	185.199.108.153	3600 A	@	185.199.109.153	3600 A	@	185.199.110.153	3600 A	@	185.199.111.153	3600  Option 2: Subdomain Configuration​  If docs.qazero.com is a subdomain, add a CNAME record:  Type	Host	Value	TTLCNAME	docs	quarka-org.github.io	3600

searchDocs.title: 3. Verify DNS Configuration​
searchDocs.content: After configuring your DNS records:  Wait for DNS propagation (can take up to 48 hours, but often completes within a few hours)Verify the configuration using: dig docs.qazero.com +noall +answer Check that the site is accessible at https://docs.qazero.com

searchDocs.title: 4. Enforce HTTPS​
searchDocs.content: Once the DNS is properly configured:  Go to the GitHub repository settingsNavigate to Pages settingsCheck the "Enforce HTTPS" option

searchDocs.title: Troubleshooting​
searchDocs.content: If the domain is not working correctly:  Verify DNS records are correctly configuredCheck that the CNAME file exists in the repositoryEnsure GitHub Pages is enabled in repository settingsCheck for any error messages in the GitHub Pages section of repository settings

searchDocs.title: General FAQ
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: What is QA ZERO?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO is a WordPress plugin that provides analytics, heatmaps, and session recording functionality to help you understand how users interact with your website.

searchDocs.title: Is QA ZERO free?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO offers both free and premium versions. The free version includes basic analytics and heatmap features, while the premium version adds advanced features like session recording, goal tracking, and AI-powered insights.

searchDocs.title: How does QA ZERO compare to Google Analytics?​
searchDocs.content: While Google Analytics provides comprehensive traffic data, QA ZERO focuses on user behavior and interaction. QA ZERO offers visual tools like heatmaps and session recordings that Google Analytics doesn't provide. Many users use both tools together for a complete picture of their website performance.

searchDocs.title: Does QA ZERO slow down my website?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO is designed to have minimal impact on your website's performance. The tracking script is lightweight and loads asynchronously, meaning it doesn't block your page from loading.

searchDocs.title: Is QA ZERO GDPR compliant?​
searchDocs.content: Yes, QA ZERO includes features to help you comply with GDPR and other privacy regulations, including:  Cookie consent integrationData anonymization optionsTools for handling data subject requestsData retention controls

searchDocs.title: Extending QA ZERO
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Creating Extensions​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO supports extensions through a simple plugin architecture:  Create a new PHP file in the extensions directoryRegister your extension using the qa_zero_register_extension functionImplement the required hooks and callbacks  Example:  <?php /** * Extension Name: My Custom Extension * Description: Adds custom functionality to QA ZERO * Version: 1.0.0 * Author: Your Name */ // Register the extension qa_zero_register_extension('my-custom-extension', array( 'title' => 'My Custom Extension', 'description' => 'Adds custom functionality to QA ZERO', 'version' => '1.0.0', 'author' => 'Your Name', 'settings' => 'my_custom_extension_settings' )); // Add settings page function my_custom_extension_settings() { // Settings page HTML } // Hook into QA ZERO add_action('qa_zero_after_track', 'my_custom_extension_callback'); // Callback function function my_custom_extension_callback($data) { // Process data }

searchDocs.title: Custom Reports​
searchDocs.content: You can create custom reports by:  Registering a new report typeImplementing the data collection functionCreating a template for displaying the report  Example:  <?php // Register custom report qa_zero_register_report('my-custom-report', array( 'title' => 'My Custom Report', 'description' => 'A custom report for QA ZERO', 'data_callback' => 'my_custom_report_data', 'template' => 'my-custom-report-template.php' )); // Data collection function function my_custom_report_data($args) { // Collect and return data return array( 'metric1' => 123, 'metric2' => 456 ); }

searchDocs.title: Custom Tracking​
searchDocs.content: You can add custom tracking by:  Adding a JavaScript file to extend the tracking functionalityRegistering the file with QA ZEROImplementing server-side handling for the custom data  Example:  <?php // Register custom tracking script qa_zero_register_script('my-custom-tracking', array( 'path' => 'js/my-custom-tracking.js', 'dependencies' => array('qa-zero-core'), 'version' => '1.0.0' )); // Handle custom tracking data add_action('wp_ajax_qa_zero_custom_track', 'my_custom_track_handler'); add_action('wp_ajax_nopriv_qa_zero_custom_track', 'my_custom_track_handler'); function my_custom_track_handler() { // Process and store custom tracking data }

searchDocs.title: How do I install QA ZERO?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO can be installed like any other WordPress plugin:  Download the plugin from the WordPress plugin repository or from our websiteUpload the plugin files to the /wp-content/plugins/qa-zero directoryActivate the plugin through the 'Plugins' menu in WordPressConfigure the plugin through the QA ZERO settings page

searchDocs.title: What are the system requirements?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO requires:  WordPress 5.5 or higherPHP 7.4 or higherMySQL 5.6 or higherModern browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)

searchDocs.title: Can I install QA ZERO on a multisite network?​
searchDocs.content: Yes, QA ZERO supports WordPress multisite installations. You can either:  Network activate the plugin to enable it for all sitesActivate it individually on specific sites

searchDocs.title: How do I update QA ZERO?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO can be updated through the WordPress admin:  Go to Dashboard > UpdatesCheck for available updatesSelect QA ZERO and click "Update Plugins"  Alternatively, you can update manually by replacing the plugin files.

searchDocs.title: What should I do if I encounter installation issues?​
searchDocs.content: If you encounter issues during installation:  Check that your system meets the requirementsDeactivate other plugins to check for conflictsTry a manual installation by uploading the files via FTPCheck the WordPress error log for specific error messagesContact support with details of the issue

searchDocs.title: Tracking Not Working​
searchDocs.content: If tracking is not working:  Check that QA ZERO is activated in your WordPress pluginsVerify that tracking is enabled in the QA ZERO settingsCheck for JavaScript errors in your browser consoleEnsure that your theme is properly loading the WordPress wp_head and wp_footer hooksTemporarily disable other plugins to check for conflicts

searchDocs.title: No Data Showing in Dashboard​
searchDocs.content: If no data is showing in the dashboard:  Verify that tracking is working (see above)Check that enough time has passed for data to be collectedEnsure that the WordPress cron is running properlyCheck the date range filter in the dashboardVerify that you have visited the site as a normal user (not logged in as admin)

searchDocs.title: Heatmaps Not Displaying Correctly​
searchDocs.content: If heatmaps are not displaying correctly:  Check that you have enough data for the selected pageVerify that the page layout hasn't changed significantly since data collectionTry adjusting the heatmap settings (opacity, radius, etc.)Clear your browser cache and try againCheck for JavaScript errors in your browser console

searchDocs.title: Performance Issues​
searchDocs.content: If you're experiencing performance issues:  Check your server resources (CPU, memory, disk space)Consider adjusting the data retention settingsOptimize your WordPress databaseReduce the amount of data being collected by configuring tracking settingsConsider upgrading your hosting plan if necessary

searchDocs.title: Error Messages​
searchDocs.content: For specific error messages:  "Database error": Check your WordPress database connection and permissions"File permission error": Check the permissions on the qa-zero-data directory"API error": Verify that your server can make outgoing connections"Configuration error": Check your QA ZERO settings

searchDocs.title: Search Implementation Security Review
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Implementation Choice​
searchDocs.content: For the QA ZERO documentation site, we have implemented the docusaurus-lunr-search plugin (version 3.6.0+) as the primary search solution. This choice was made based on the following security considerations:

searchDocs.title: Security Considerations​
searchDocs.content: Client-side Search: The plugin performs all search operations on the client side, eliminating the need for external API calls or server-side processing. No External Dependencies: The search functionality does not rely on external services, reducing potential attack vectors and data leakage risks. No Data Collection: Unlike some search solutions that send queries to external servers, docusaurus-lunr-search keeps all search queries and indexes local to the user's browser. Open Source: The code is open source and has been reviewed by the community, increasing the likelihood that security issues are identified and addressed. Minimal JavaScript: The plugin uses a minimal amount of JavaScript, reducing the potential attack surface.

searchDocs.title: Code Audit Results​
searchDocs.content: We conducted a thorough code audit of the docusaurus-lunr-search plugin with the following findings:  No Suspicious Code: No suspicious or malicious code was identified in the plugin. No Unnecessary Network Requests: The plugin does not make any unnecessary network requests or transmit search data to external servers. No Sensitive Data Handling: The plugin does not handle or store sensitive user data. Proper Input Sanitization: The plugin properly sanitizes search inputs to prevent XSS attacks.

searchDocs.title: Version Management​
searchDocs.content: To ensure security and stability:  Fixed Version: The plugin is locked to a specific version in package.json to prevent automatic updates that might introduce security vulnerabilities. Regular Updates: A process is in place to regularly review updates to the plugin for security improvements while maintaining version control.

searchDocs.title: Multilingual Support​
searchDocs.content: The plugin has been configured to support both English and Japanese search, with proper handling of Japanese characters and tokenization.

searchDocs.title: Option 2: Basic Search Functionality​
searchDocs.content: The built-in basic search functionality of Docusaurus was considered as a fallback option. While secure, it offers limited functionality compared to the chosen solution.

searchDocs.title: Option 3: @easyops-cn/docusaurus-search-local​
searchDocs.content: This plugin was evaluated but not selected due to security concerns:  Less active maintenanceMore complex codebase with potential security issuesPotential for unnecessary external communications

searchDocs.title: Conclusion​
searchDocs.content: Based on our security review, docusaurus-lunr-search provides the best balance of functionality and security for the QA ZERO documentation site. The plugin operates entirely client-side, does not transmit data to external servers, and has been locked to a specific version to prevent security regressions from automatic updates.

searchDocs.title: Future Improvements​
searchDocs.content: Potential future improvements to search security include:  Regular security audits of the plugin as new versions are releasedConsideration of implementing Content Security Policy (CSP) headers to further restrict potential script executionMonitoring for any security advisories related to the Lunr.js library that powers the search functionality

searchDocs.title: Configure the Sidebar​
searchDocs.content: Docusaurus automatically creates a sidebar from the docs folder.  Add metadata to customize the sidebar label and position:  docs/hello.md --- sidebar_label: 'Hi!' sidebar_position: 3 --- # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**!   It is also possible to create your sidebar explicitly in sidebars.js:  sidebars.js export default { tutorialSidebar: [ 'intro', 'hello', { type: 'category', label: 'Tutorial', items: ['tutorial-basics/create-a-document'], }, ], };

searchDocs.title: Create a Blog Post
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Create your first Post​
searchDocs.content: Create a file at blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md:  blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md --- slug: greetings title: Greetings! authors: - name: Joel Marcey title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1 url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey image_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey.png - name: Sébastien Lorber title: Docusaurus maintainer url: https://sebastienlorber.com image_url: https://github.com/slorber.png tags: [greetings] --- Congratulations, you have made your first post! Feel free to play around and edit this post as much as you like.   A new blog post is now available at http://localhost:3000/blog/greetings.

searchDocs.title: Deploy your site
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Build your site​
searchDocs.content: Build your site for production:  npm run build   The static files are generated in the build folder.

searchDocs.title: Deploy your site​
searchDocs.content: Test your production build locally:  npm run serve   The build folder is now served at http://localhost:3000/.  You can now deploy the build folder almost anywhere easily, for free or very small cost (read the Deployment Guide).

searchDocs.title: Create a Page
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Create your first React Page​
searchDocs.content: Create a file at src/pages/my-react-page.js:  src/pages/my-react-page.js import React from 'react'; import Layout from '@theme/Layout'; export default function MyReactPage() { return ( <Layout> <h1>My React page</h1> <p>This is a React page</p> </Layout> ); }   A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-react-page.

searchDocs.title: Create your first Markdown Page​
searchDocs.content: Create a file at src/pages/my-markdown-page.md:  src/pages/my-markdown-page.md # My Markdown page This is a Markdown page   A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-markdown-page.

searchDocs.title: Manage Docs Versions
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Create a docs version​
searchDocs.content: Release a version 1.0 of your project:  npm run docusaurus docs:version 1.0   The docs folder is copied into versioned_docs/version-1.0 and versions.json is created.  Your docs now have 2 versions:  1.0 at http://localhost:3000/docs/ for the version 1.0 docscurrent at http://localhost:3000/docs/next/ for the upcoming, unreleased docs

searchDocs.title: Add a Version Dropdown​
searchDocs.content: To navigate seamlessly across versions, add a version dropdown.  Modify the docusaurus.config.js file:  docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'docsVersionDropdown', }, ], }, }, };   The docs version dropdown appears in your navbar:

searchDocs.title: Update an existing version​
searchDocs.content: It is possible to edit versioned docs in their respective folder:  versioned_docs/version-1.0/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/hellodocs/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/next/hello

searchDocs.title: Markdown Features
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Front Matter​
searchDocs.content: Markdown documents have metadata at the top called Front Matter:  my-doc.md --- id: my-doc-id title: My document title description: My document description slug: /my-custom-url --- ## Markdown heading Markdown text with [links](./hello.md)

searchDocs.title: Links​
searchDocs.content: Regular Markdown links are supported, using url paths or relative file paths.  Let's see how to [Create a page](/create-a-page).   Let's see how to [Create a page](./create-a-page.md).   Result: Let's see how to Create a page.

searchDocs.title: Images​
searchDocs.content: Regular Markdown images are supported.  You can use absolute paths to reference images in the static directory (static/img/docusaurus.png):  ![Docusaurus logo](/img/docusaurus.png)     You can reference images relative to the current file as well. This is particularly useful to colocate images close to the Markdown files using them:  ![Docusaurus logo](./img/docusaurus.png)

searchDocs.title: Code Blocks​
searchDocs.content: Markdown code blocks are supported with Syntax highlighting.  ```jsx title="src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js" function HelloDocusaurus() { return <h1>Hello, Docusaurus!</h1>; } ```   src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js function HelloDocusaurus() { return <h1>Hello, Docusaurus!</h1>; }

searchDocs.title: Admonitions​
searchDocs.content: Docusaurus has a special syntax to create admonitions and callouts:  :::tip[My tip] Use this awesome feature option ::: :::danger[Take care] This action is dangerous :::   My tip Use this awesome feature option  Take care This action is dangerous

searchDocs.title: MDX and React Components​
searchDocs.content: MDX can make your documentation more interactive and allows using any React components inside Markdown:  export const Highlight = ({children, color}) => ( <span style={{ backgroundColor: color, borderRadius: '20px', color: '#fff', padding: '10px', cursor: 'pointer', }} onClick={() => { alert(`You clicked the color ${color} with label ${children}`) }}> {children} </span> ); This is <Highlight color="#25c2a0">Docusaurus green</Highlight> ! This is <Highlight color="#1877F2">Facebook blue</Highlight> !     This is Docusaurus green !  This is Facebook blue !

searchDocs.title: Translate your site
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: Configure i18n​
searchDocs.content: Modify docusaurus.config.js to add support for the fr locale:  docusaurus.config.js export default { i18n: { defaultLocale: 'en', locales: ['en', 'fr'], }, };

searchDocs.title: Translate a doc​
searchDocs.content: Copy the docs/intro.md file to the i18n/fr folder:  mkdir -p i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/ cp docs/intro.md i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md   Translate i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md in French.

searchDocs.title: Start your localized site​
searchDocs.content: Start your site on the French locale:  npm run start -- --locale fr   Your localized site is accessible at http://localhost:3000/fr/ and the Getting Started page is translated.  注意 In development, you can only use one locale at a time.

searchDocs.title: Add a Locale Dropdown​
searchDocs.content: To navigate seamlessly across languages, add a locale dropdown.  Modify the docusaurus.config.js file:  docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'localeDropdown', }, ], }, }, };   The locale dropdown now appears in your navbar:

searchDocs.title: Build your localized site​
searchDocs.content: Build your site for a specific locale:  npm run build -- --locale fr   Or build your site to include all the locales at once:  npm run build

searchDocs.title: Introduction to QA ZERO
searchDocs.keywords: QA ZERO  WordPress  analytics  heatmap  documentation

searchDocs.title: What is QA ZERO?​
searchDocs.content: QA ZERO is a comprehensive WordPress plugin for website analytics and heatmap functionality. It enables website administrators to:  Track page views, sessions, and user interactionsGenerate heatmaps to visualize user behaviorRecord and replay user sessionsSet up and track conversion goals

searchDocs.title: Key Features​
searchDocs.content: Analytics Dashboard: View comprehensive statistics about your website trafficHeatmap Visualization: See where users click and interact with your pagesSession Recording: Watch recordings of actual user sessionsGoal Tracking: Set up conversion goals and track their performance

searchDocs.title: Getting Started​
searchDocs.content: To get started with QA ZERO, proceed to the Getting Started section.
